body_html:
Yes, it works. I followed the answer of @leftofcenter .
In the path of python which you installed on you target machine, and find the directory of "dist-packages" or "site-packages":

find -type f -name 'Tensor' -print
maybe the output:
/tensorflow/include/third_party/eigen3/unsupported/Eigen/CXX11/Tensor

So, you can copy the directory "unsupported/" to where you place the reference header files. For example,

sudo cp -r ***/site-packages/tensorflow/include/unsupported/ /usr/local/include/google/tensorflow/

And, you must also copy another folder of "Eigen" in "***/site-packages/tensorflow/include/"

sudo cp -r ***/site-packages/tensorflow/include/Eigen/ /usr/local/include/google/tensorflow/

find -type f -name 'Tensor' -print

body:
Yes, it works. I followed the answer of @leftofcenter .
In the path of python which you installed on you target machine, and find the directory of "dist-packages" or "site-packages":

> find -type f -name 'Tensor' -print
maybe the output:
/tensorflow/include/third_party/eigen3/unsupported/Eigen/CXX11/Tensor

So, you can copy the directory "unsupported/" to where you place the reference header files. For example, 

> sudo cp -r ***/site-packages/tensorflow/include/unsupported/ /usr/local/include/google/tensorflow/

And, you must also copy another folder of "Eigen" in "***/site-packages/tensorflow/include/"

> sudo cp -r ***/site-packages/tensorflow/include/Eigen/ /usr/local/include/google/tensorflow/
